text: are we doomed have we passed the point
of no return are we destroying the
planet the environment the natural world
and ourselves these questions are coming
up a lot lately as anxiety about global
warming and other environmental
catastrophes grows no movie I think has
dealt with these fears with quite the
complexity in nuance as Princess
Mononoke by Hayao Miyazaki there is evil
at work in the land to the west Prince
ashitaka it's your fate to go there and
see what you can see with eyes unclouded
by hate you may find a way to lift the
curse Miyazaki is one of Japan's
greatest living filmmakers he works
entirely in animation and Japanese anime
is different from its Hollywood
counterpart it's not just for children
for one thing it encompasses a range of
styles and subject matters and genres
and in the case of Miyazaki it also
shows a great painterly sense especially
the landscapes which Miyazaki renders
with a delicacy reminiscent of Monet or
tournament
Princess Mononoke has some resemblances
to standard Disney films or classic
Western fairytales it's about a young
man who sets off and has a lot of
different adventures fighting beasts and
falling in love with a beautiful maiden
but the core of it is this young man's
involvement in a war between the
citizens and rulers of iron town and the
surrounding forests and the enchanted
creatures who inhabit it
but in Miyazaki's world is never a
matter of a simple struggle between good
and evil the sides keep switching and
our sympathies along with the filmmakers
keep being drawn back and forth so that
the citizens of iron town are
hardworking and decent but also greedy
and duplicitous and short-sighted and
the enchanted creatures of the forest
the spirits that are so magical and
beautiful and Noble are also monstrous
now this allegorical struggle between
human civilization and the natural world
is not one that can be resolved with a
clear victory for either side and there
is a somewhat hopeful conclusion in
Princess Mononoke it's that this
relationship is a cycle that human
beings can learn how to manage their
antagonism with nature in such a way
that both civilization and the natural
world can survive but Miyazaki's film
also takes a longer view which is that
eventually this cycle will end and it
can only end one way
you
